stem: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the assessment findings, match the intervention to the physiological process it addresses.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Removing the noxious stimuli resolves the precipitating cause of autonomic dysreflexia, thereby reducing the exaggerated sympathetic response and lowering blood pressure. Elevating the head of the bed promotes venous pooling, reducing venous return and subsequently decreasing blood pressure. Administering antihypertensive medication directly addresses the elevated blood pressure, mitigating the risk of complications such as stroke or seizure. Monitoring blood pressure frequently allows for timely assessment of the effectiveness of interventions and guides further management decisions.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: Search for the cause, Identify the stimulus, Treat the BP, Urgently act, Prevent recurrence

rationale.incorrect: Administering oxygen may be appropriate if hypoxemia is present, but it does not directly address the underlying cause or the elevated blood pressure in autonomic dysreflexia. Increasing IV fluids can exacerbate hypertension in this condition. Applying restraints is contraindicated as it can increase agitation and potentially worsen the autonomic response. Initiating a bladder training program is not an immediate intervention for autonomic dysreflexia and is a long-term rehabilitation goal.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus solely on the high blood pressure and choose only the antihypertensive medication without considering the importance of identifying and removing the noxious stimulus.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of addressing the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia, not just treating the symptoms. Prioritize interventions that remove the noxious stimuli.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Always prioritize identifying and removing the noxious stimulus.
Educate patients with spinal cord injuries and their caregivers about the signs, symptoms, and management of autonomic dysreflexia.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Tyrell, 38-year-old male with T6 spinal cord injury, admitted for rehabilitation. B: Patient sustained injury 6 months ago in a motor vehicle accident. He has been managing his bowel and bladder regimen at home with assistance. At 08:00 today, patient reported a throbbing headache and feeling flushed. A: At 08:15, assessment revealed BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 52 bpm, nasal congestion, and diaphoresis above the level of injury. Patient reports feeling anxious. I&O catheter is in place and draining clear urine. Bowel movement was last noted two days ago. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Skin intact except for expected pressure points. R: I suspect autonomic dysreflexia. I recommend checking the urinary catheter for kinks, assessing for bowel impaction, and administering PRN nifedipine 10 mg SL for BP control. Monitor BP every 5 minutes and notify provider if BP remains elevated after 15 minutes.

correctResponse.Remove the noxious stimuli: Resolves the cause of autonomic dysreflexia

rows: Elevate the head of the bed
columns: Resolves the cause of autonomic dysreflexia
